I.</br>'Twas but late the mourning year,</br>Felt the force of Winter drear,</br>When from forth his chill abode</br>Clad in double night he rode,</br>Scatt'ring with his blighting breath,</br>Hail, and terror, storms, and death.</br>Now let Spring her form unfold,</br>Robed in green and gem'd with gold.</br>Lo!  she comes, by Zephyrs led,</br>(Blooms unnumber'd round her head)</br>Over valley, hill, and grove,</br>Breathing life, and health, and love.

II.</br>Wake, my soul, with vigour new,</br>Give the Goddess welcome due!</br>As she moves, the laughing hours</br>Fill the gladden'd earth with flowers,</br>And the placid waters pour</br>Myriads round the sea-girt shore,</br>And throughout the lucid sky,</br>(Emblem of the Deity)</br>Lo!  the glorious source of day,</br>Bounteous spreads his procreant ray.

III.</br>Let me, bounding o'er the heath,</br>Revel in its scented breath;</br>Or the rugged mountain climb,</br>Plucking oft the luscious thyme,</br>While the shepherd boy is near,</br>Mindful of his fleecy care,</br>Leaning o'er the shaded style,</br>(Simply carolling the while)</br>Shore's or Rosamonda's fall,</br>Or some pensive madrigal,</br>Where the Muse in artless lays,</br>Tells the cares of ancient days.

IV.</br>Now I seek the quiet grove,</br>Where the ring-dove woos his love;</br>Where, beneath each spreading tree,</br>Clust'ring grows the strawberry;</br>And the tangling underwood,</br>Frequent turns the devious road,</br>Till a sloping lawn I cross,</br>Girt with oak, and soft with moss,</br>Whose deep bosom thick is set</br>With the purple violet,</br>And the orchis rears his head</br>Spiral from its velvet bed.</br>Here, an ancient legend says,</br>Nightly sport the laughing Fays,</br>Though by mortals seldom seen,</br>Nightly foot the dasied green.

V.</br>Me, thick-coming fancies lead,</br>Oft to this sequester'd mead;</br>When the moon with silv'ry light,</br>Half unveils the form of night,</br>And o'er ev'ry scene hath thrown,</br>Deep solemnity of tone:</br>Then, methinks, I range the glade,</br>Where of old young Spenser stray'd,</br>While his fairy tutors shed</br>Dreams delicious o'er his head:</br>Doth my spirit loftier soar?</br>Loftier visions round me pour:</br>Then, these shades appear the grove</br>Mighty Milton lov'd to rove,</br>When in thought the poet stood,</br>Firm beside the Stygian flood,</br>Gazing on the dread profound!</br>Or when on empyreal ground</br>Ranged the holy groups among,</br>Rapt!  he breath'd seraphic song.

VI.</br>Heard ye not his voice divine?</br>With such sounds the holy nine</br>Fill'd the star-pav'd courts above,</br>When they hymn'd their parent Jove.</br>Once, again, that noble strain,</br>Sun-bright Fancy, once again!</br>Ah!  vain wish!  the niggard Muse,</br>Doth to modern brows refuse,</br>Ev'ry wreath, but that, the meed</br>Of the lute, or pastoral reed,</br>Hiding in her secret cell</br>The ancient, lofty, epic shell.

VII.</br>Roaming on, the place I find,</br>Where full oft, my lifted mind,</br>Joying at the op'ning sight,</br>Deeply drinks the rich delight.</br>Gradual hills of tend'rest blue,</br>Which their pure atherial hue</br>O'er the distance lovely shed,</br>Like radiance from a sainted head.</br>Herds, and flocks, and verdant woods,</br>Murm'ring streams, and rapid floods,</br>Forests, dark with sturdy oak,</br>Fearless of the woodman's stroke;</br>Rocks abrupt, that reach the skies,</br>On whose cultur'd margin rise</br>Many a cottage, fenced around</br>With a well-filled piece of ground,</br>Where the elder villagers,</br>Quite forget the weight of years,</br>As their childrens' children play</br>Round them on a holiday:</br>See!  they climb their aged knees,</br>Fraught with little arts to please:</br>See!  they lay their dimples sleek,</br>Fondly to each furrow'd cheek,</br>And with kisses sweet as May,</br>Press the tears of joy away.

VIII.</br>Oft the weary traveller's feet</br>Rest in yonder calm retreat;</br>And the humble habitants,</br>Glad to aid his little wants,</br>Haste the nutbrown jug to fill</br>With beverage suited to his will;</br>Fresh drawn milk, or home-brew'd ale,</br>Season'd with some merry tale</br>That befel at sheep-shearing:</br>While they talk, their young one's bring</br>All the orchard can afford,</br>And bespread the friendly board;</br>Culling, for their welcome guest,</br>All the ripest and the best</br>Grateful, he repays the cheer,</br>With the tales they love to hear</br>Of the ghosts that shrouded stalk,</br>In the frighted pilgrims walk;</br>While the simple family</br>Scared, yet pleas'd, stand list'ning by.

IX.</br>Where the scene is dark with yew,</br>Solemn rising on the view,</br>Lo!  a gothic pile appears,</br>Touch'd, but not impair'd by years.</br>See!  a youth with modest pride</br>To its altar leads his bride,</br>Who with timid downcast eyes,</br>Hopes, and blushes!  fears, and sighs!</br>As the priest, with saintly look</br>Pious opes the holy book;</br>And their parents, standing near,</br>Raise to heaven the eye of prayer.</br>Go, ye blessed!  go and prove</br>That the heaven of life — is love!</br>Not that wild misguided flame,</br>Borrowing oft the noble name;</br>Which like withering light'ning flies,</br>Lives to wound, and wounding dies;</br>But that pure, that lasting heat,</br>Minds in minds congenial meet,</br>When fair virtues simple train,</br>Own the maiden and the swain.

X.</br>Lo!  from yonder mountains brow,</br>Balmy showers descending slow,</br>Over hill, and wood, and dale,</br>Gently throw a misty veil.</br>Underneath the shelter now</br>Of the oak's wide spreading bough,</br>Charm'd I rest, and hear the note</br>Of the thrashes tuneful throat;</br>Or the blackbirds' whistle clear,</br>Sweetly pierce the thicken'd air.</br>Or, perchance, the darken'd noon,</br>Urges Philomel so soon</br>To delight the plains and me,</br>With her perfect melody.

XI.</br>But if these their song deny,</br>Fancy, to my mental eye,</br>Spreads her forms of various hue,</br>Rudely drawn, but colour'd true;</br>Then I see, in dews of May,</br>Autumn's corn, and summer's hay,</br>And behold the rustic feast,</br>Where I sit a bidden guest:</br>All the care collected hoard,</br>Safe, within the barn is stor'd;</br>And the farmer's honest face</br>To his welcome, gives a grace,</br>Such as art, concealing hate,</br>Vainly strives to imitate;</br>While his hardy sun-burnt bands;</br>Gathering round us, join their hands,</br>Till the old, but sturdy dome</br>Trembles to their harvest-home.

XII.</br>Homeward now, my steps I trace,</br>Hungry, and with hurried pace;</br>Those, whom most I joy to see,</br>At my threshold meeting me;</br>While their ardent features shine</br>With a joy, that equals mine.</br>Round the festive board we sit,</br>Joy, and health, awaken wit;</br>Playful wit, whose darts are found</br>All to strike, but none to wound.

XIII.</br>Or, if serious, we would know</br>What our bards, illumin'd, show;</br>Whether to the varied page</br>Of the early gifted sage,</br>Who his rich ideas drest</br>In a loose, but comely vest;</br>Or, to him, the drama's source,</br>Who his wild, eccentric course,</br>Like a fiery comet holds,</br>And within his sphere enfolds</br>Ev'ry passion's latent cause;</br>Scorning all the narrow laws,</br>Which the critic strives to bind</br>Vainly round his mighty mind:</br>Whether 'tis to these we turn,</br>Or to pity-moving Sterne;</br>Thou, the parent of my fame,</br>You, whose warmth preserv'd the flame,</br>Which was dying in my breast,</br>By cold penury opprest;</br>Thou, my dear, my early friend,</br>Thou shalt read, and we'll attend,</br>Till each soul, impassion'd wears</br>Joy for joy, and grief for tears.

XIV.</br>Through the garden now we'll range;</br>View its sweets and mark their change;</br>Beauteous fav'rites of a day!</br>Oh!  how sweet the breath of May!</br>Oh!  how rich her form appears,</br>Bounteous smiling thro' her tears,</br>As the day-star riding high,</br>Clears the lately clouded sky!</br>—Never let my banks be free,</br>From the flaunting piony;</br>Or the flower that bears the name</br>Of the never dying flame;</br>Or the tulip's pencil'd bell,</br>Or the pink, with spicy smell:</br>While beside them lovely grows</br>Flora's pride, the mossy rose,</br>And the lily's breast of snow</br>Blends the heaven-tinctur'd glow:</br>Let the hollyhock be nigh,</br>Deeply steep'd in purple dye;</br>I delight to see him drest</br>In his dark imperial vest,</br>Branching wide, and waving loose,</br>Drunk he seems with Tyrian juice.

XV.</br>Never wilt thou glad mine eyes,</br>Song ennobled Helichrise!</br>Arethusa's banks of old,</br>Used to shine with loveliest gold,</br>While her sacred shades among,</br>Thick thy clust'ring berries hung:</br>But the doric shepherd died!</br>And e'er since, thy grief to hide,</br>Thou hast droop'd in cavern drear,</br>Shrinking from the balmy air!</br>Who shall raise a simple strain,</br>Luring thee to life again?</br>This, the Mantuan youth essay'd,</br>And his pipe, enchanting play'd;</br>But so much of art was found</br>In the smooth, the polish'd sound,</br>That thy half uplifted head</br>Sought again its sullen bed.</br>—Thee I lack!  but still my bower</br>Shines with many a lovely flower;</br>At its entrance, close entwine,</br>Suckling sweet and eglantine;</br>Round its side the blossom'd May</br>Loves with twisted branch to stray,</br>And the jas'min as his mate,</br>Slender, sweet, and delicate.</br>There the vine, her tender boughs</br>Round the oak luxuriant throws,</br>Hiding in his vig'rous arms,</br>Like a bride, her blushing charms;</br>Emblem of the first embrace,</br>His the strength, and her's the grace.

XVI.</br>Dear, delicious, favor'd gloom,</br>Form'd of all that breathes perfume,</br>Oh!  how sweet it is to lie</br>In thy rich obscurity!</br>List'ning, while the Zephyrs bring</br>Sylvan sounds on ev'ry wing;</br>Hearing each, and charm'd with all,</br>Whether 'tis the gentle call</br>Of the woodlark to his mate,</br>Sweetly soothing!  or the prate</br>Of the neighb'ring rookery,</br>When it holds a synod high.</br>Sometimes comes the tink'ling bell</br>Of the sheep in yonder dell;</br>Sometimes when the shepherd plays,</br>Though far off, I catch the lays:</br>But more dear the jocund noise</br>Of the pipe's and tabor's voice,</br>When the festal day is spent</br>By young and old in merriment;</br>I their laughter love to hear,</br>Sometimes distant, sometimes near,</br>Floating in the genial air:</br>All the while the painted fly</br>Skims before my roving eye;</br>And the bee through aether borne,</br>Winds in joy her little horn,</br>And the balm of opening blooms.</br>Drinks, to fill her waxen combs;</br>Bearing from each flow'ry stem</br>Food for her, and joy for them:</br>When the pollen form'd to rove,</br>Flies with her to find its love;</br>Who, with ripen'd blushes spread,</br>Waits patient in her nuptial bed.

XVII.</br>—Sometimes, holy Harmony</br>Here shall breathe her sweetest sigh;</br>Such as nature, source of truth,</br>Taught her, in her early youth,</br>When as yet the immortal maid</br>Lovely, and unfetter'd stray'd:</br>Then her power could steep distress</br>In a glad forgetfulness;</br>And when Vengeance heard the lay,</br>All his rage was charm'd away;</br>From his bare, his blood-stain'd arm</br>Drop'd the standard of alarm;</br>While upon her honied tongue,</br>Fond, the soft'ned savage hung.

XVIII.</br>—Here the Muses oft shall come,</br>Fav'ring kind my humble home;</br>Often, my desiring ear,</br>With full chorus'd numbers cheer;</br>As their thoughts divinely rise,</br>Tranc'd in joy my spirit lies;</br>Or, upborne their strains upon,</br>Drinks the dews of Helicon.</br>If my beating heart should store</br>But in part the sacred lore,</br>My weak numbers form'd thereon,</br>Still shall live, when I am gone!</br>Fond thought!!</br>But oh!  inspir'd maid,</br>Never thou, forsake my shade;</br>Thou, who mute, dost language use,</br>Powerful as the vocal muse:</br>Thee my infant choice approv'd,</br>Thee I woo'd, for thee I lov'd.</br>Often, when the orient ray</br>Spoke the near approach of day;</br>Often, when the evening mild,</br>Dewy mantled, wept and smil'd;</br>Often, at the solemn time,</br>When the pale moon rode sublime,</br>Thou hast heard my ardent prayer,</br>Heard, and not disdain'd to hear;</br>For, around my pillow'd head</br>Oft thy perfect forms were spread;</br>And delicious Hope the while</br>Cheer'd me with her magic smile;</br>And in sweet prophetic lays</br>Whisper'd me of coming days.

XIX.</br>Never then deny to roll</br>Thy bright visions o'er my soul:</br>Lo!  they come!  I feel their power,</br>Glowing phantoms fill the bower!</br>Deep within the lesbian grove</br>Sapho chaunts the hymn of love!</br>See her soft, her azure eyes</br>Beam with growing extacies!</br>As she sings, the son of war</br>Leaps from off the rushing car;</br>And the hunter quits the chase;</br>And the youth of swiftest pace</br>Leaves the yet unfinish'd race!</br>As she pours the mystic song,</br>Joy and rapture fill the throng!</br>See the lovely Lyrist round,</br>See they press the mossy ground!</br>See, their blushing heads they raise</br>Frequent with the voice of praise;</br>But the trembling accent dies</br>All away in longing sighs!!

XX.</br>—Oh!  that I the forms could give,</br>Strong as in my thoughts they live;</br>When the rich, the perfect whole,</br>Comes in splendour on my soul!</br>My broad canvas then should show</br>Warm with life's divinest glow!</br>So that those who came to gaze,</br>Fix'd should stand in fond amaze;</br>And, in anxious clusters round,</br>Wait impatient for the sound!

XXI.</br>Now when falls a lengthen'd shade,</br>And the healthy dairy maid</br>Homeward trips with brimful pail;</br>Now when silent is the flail,</br>And the swallow, welcome guest,</br>Twitters round her growing nest;</br>And the bat, with giddy flight,</br>Cheats the vain pursuing sight;</br>While the sturdy peasants wait</br>Loit'ring at the' homested gate,</br>And with boist'rous mirth foretel</br>Who the champion list shall swell,</br>Wielding best the oaken stake</br>At the near approaching wake:</br>We up yonder hill will stray,</br>Where the latter beams of day</br>Love to linger, love to play.

XXII.</br>Now the sun, who western far,</br>Downward drives his rapid car,</br>Seems his sacred locks to lave</br>In the broad atlantic wave,</br>Leaving in his progress bright</br>Streams of many colour'd light;</br>See, they vary!  see, they fade!</br>Over all is now display'd</br>One broad tint, more dear to me</br>Even than variety!</br>Mark where yonder glassy stream</br>Glad reflects a ling'ring beam;</br>Mark too, where the rising smoke,</br>Tinges soft the aged oak;</br>Showing to our searching eyes</br>Where the hidden village lies;</br>While beneath us all the vale</br>Echoes to the nightingale,</br>And the owl (her screeching tongue</br>Shamed to silence,) hears the song.

XXIII.</br>Hail, grey-bosom'd Twilight!  hail!</br>Never, never, may I fail</br>With a vot'ry's zeal to wait</br>On thy mild, thy placid state;</br>I around thy modest head</br>Charm'd behold the planets spread;</br>Raptur'd see the starry blaze</br>Widening still its pearly rays,</br>Till at length the galaxy</br>Glows across the vaulted sky.

XXIV.</br>—Such the joys, enchanting Spring!</br>Which thy genial moments bring:</br>Not when Summer scents the glade</br>With her wreath of hay new made;</br>Not when Autumn's liberal hand</br>Scatters plenty, o'er the laud:</br>Not e'en then will I compare,</br>Sweetest season of the year!</br>Either of their charms with those</br>Which thy lucid veils disclose,</br>When thou com'st in gentle showers,</br>Braiding thy bright hair with flowers.</br>Sweetest season of the year!</br>Winter, when he sees thee near,</br>Throws aside his robe of snow,</br>Smiles, and smooths his rugged brow.</br>Often too attempts to rest</br>His boar head upon thy breast;</br>But, when he perceives thy wreath</br>Dying by his chilling breath,</br>Sad he turns, and rushing forth,</br>Hides him in the stormy north:</br>Then the vegetable race</br>Feel thy long desir'd embrace;</br>And the God, who gave it birth,</br>Seems to walk the blossom'd earth.</br>
